name: Checklist IV (For International Ship and Port Facility Security)
description: A checklist for verifying compliance with the International Ship and Port Facility Security (ISPS) Code before entering port.

items.text: Is a valid International Ship Security Certificate (ISSC) or Interim ISSC on board?
Is the latest approved Ship Security Plan (SSP) available?
Is the current Security Level of the ship and the next port of call known and being adhered to?
Is there documentary evidence of the declaration of the Company Security Officer (CSO) for the vessel?
Does the designated Ship Security Officer (SSO) hold a valid certificate?
items.details: Is there documentary evidence for the assignment of the SSO by the CSO?

items.text: Do crew members hold valid certification in security awareness training or training for designated security duties?
Has a Declaration of Security (DoS) been exchanged with the port authority of the next port of call, if required?
Are all security records kept in the working language of the ship?
items.details: If the language is not English, French, or Spanish, a translation into one of those languages must be included.

items.text: Are records of security trainings, drills, and exercises properly maintained?
items.details: Check records for drills, especially if more than 25% of the crew have been changed.

items.text: Are records of changes in security level and communications relating to the direct security of the ship available?
Are records of periodic reviews of the Ship Security Assessment (SSA) and Ship Security Plan (SSP) maintained?
Are records of internal security audits available?
Are records for maintenance, calibration, and testing of the Ship Security Alert System (SSAS) maintained?
Is a record of the last 10 calls at port facilities available?
Does the crew know who the Company Security Officer (CSO) is?
Does the crew know who the Ship Security Officer (SSO) is?
Does the crew know where the designated access point will be during the port stay?
Does the assigned crew know how to control and log all visitors and their effects?
Does the crew know the location of restricted areas and how they are to be controlled?
items.details: Check familiarity with monitoring of deck and ship surroundings.

items.text: Is the crew familiar with how the loading of cargo, ship's stores, and spare parts is to be controlled?
Does the crew know when and how a stowaway search is to be conducted?
